body_html: In the workspace.bzl, tensorflow binds @protubuf to the protobuf repository, while https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/master/WORKSPACE binds @protobuf to the build target (not the repo). Suppose I have a third repository and pulling in both tensorflow and grpc as external repositories, the build will fail due to name clash, the error message is something like external/protobuf does not have attribute testonly, which basically says Bazel is trying to use @protobuf as a target but in fact the name is pulled in as a repo by tensorflow.
body_text: In the workspace.bzl, tensorflow binds @protubuf to the protobuf repository, while https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/master/WORKSPACE binds @protobuf to the build target (not the repo). Suppose I have a third repository and pulling in both tensorflow and grpc as external repositories, the build will fail due to name clash, the error message is something like external/protobuf does not have attribute testonly, which basically says Bazel is trying to use @protobuf as a target but in fact the name is pulled in as a repo by tensorflow.
body: In the workspace.bzl, tensorflow binds @protubuf to the protobuf repository, while https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/master/WORKSPACE binds @protobuf to the build target (not the repo). Suppose I have a third repository and pulling in both tensorflow and grpc as external repositories, the build will fail due to name clash, the error message is something like external/protobuf does not have attribute testonly, which basically says Bazel is trying to use @protobuf as a target but in fact the name is pulled in as a repo by tensorflow.
